entry.title: Armenia takes $256M loan for major road project: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: Armenia takes $256M loan for major road project: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìç The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development agreed to loan Armenia more than $256 million for a major road project in the country‚Äôs southernmost Syunik region. üìç Stock prices of the Bank of Georgia Group, the company that owns Ameriabank, one of Armenia‚Äôs biggest lenders, plunged as markets reacted to the Georgian government‚Äôs move to push forward with controversial legislation that may derail that country‚Äôs efforts to join the European Union.

entry.title: ‚ÄòRelease Armenian prisoners before climate summit‚Äô: Ruben Vardanyan‚Äôs family to Azerbaijan

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄòRelease Armenian prisoners before climate summit‚Äô: Ruben Vardanyan‚Äôs family to Azerbaijan
media:group.media:description:
üìç The head of Armenia‚Äôs Security Council sought to allay worries about the border demarcation in Armenia‚Äôs northeastern Tavush region as exact coordinates have been decided upon. üìç Ruben Vardanyan‚Äôs family has called on the international community to demand the unconditional release of Armenian detainees held by Azerbaijan or disallow Baku to host the upcoming COP29 climate summit. üìç Meeting held in Geneva between the Armenian and Azerbaijani parliament speakers.

entry.title: Armenia launches housing program for displaced Nagorno-Karabakh families

media:group.media:title: Armenia launches housing program for displaced Nagorno-Karabakh families
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia and Azerbaijan signed a protocol confirming the coordinates of the border delimitation process determined in Tavush. üìç The Armenian government approved a state support program to provide housing for families forcibly displaced from Nagorno-Karabakh who become Armenian citizens. üìç The detention period has been extended for Ruben Vardanyan and the other former Nagorno-Karabakh officials who are being held by Azerbaijan. üìçAssessing support for Archbishop Galstanyan‚Äôs protest movement https://youtu.be/tNQ11SyxAxQ

entry.title: Assessing support for Archbishop Galstanyan‚Äôs protest movement

media:group.media:title: Assessing support for Archbishop Galstanyan‚Äôs protest movement
media:group.media:description:
This week on Insights, host Eric Hacopian continues his analysis of Archbishop Bagrat Galstanyan's protest march from Tavush to Yerevan. He closely examines the goals and message behind the high-profile demonstrations, and considers what the civil unrest means for Armenia's political landscape going forward.

media:group.media:title: Blockchain, tech and human connection #shorts
media:group.media:description:
In this episode of Mindful Leaders, we explore the life of Stephany Sanossian, an artist and designer. Born in Aleppo, Syria, to Armenian parents with ancestral roots from Aintab, Stephany is an artist with a background in design. She left Syria to pursue her studies and passion in Barcelona, after which she settled in Dubai. Stephany‚Äôs life journey is a testament to her passion for and dedication to tradition combined with innovation. Her artwork interlaces the charm of Middle Eastern and Armenian art with contemporary flavors, complexities, and perspectives. Her collages and installations have gained global recognition and are showcased in exhibitions and pavilions worldwide. In this episode, we discuss the role of nostalgia and collective memories, the greater importance of human connections, and a vision for a more authentic and meaningful life.
